text:
The next time you’re in Hamburg, Bremen,
Lübeck, Rostock, Lüneburg, or any of these

cities across northern Germany, take a look
at their license plates.

Since German license plates show the city
that the car was registered in, you can see
the abbreviations of every city in Germany.

With this in mind, you might have noticed
that all the cities I just mentioned have

abbreviations starting with H, even cities
like Lübeck and Bremen, so why do they have
an H in them?

Short answer, a little something called the
Hanseatic League.
[Sponsored by NordVPN]

The Hanseatic League was a merchant union
between many of the great trading cities across

the Northern and Baltic Seas, stretching from
Brügges in modern-day Belgium to Riga in

modern-day Latvia, and even with presences
in Finland, Norway, and England.

However, their main players were many of the
cities across northern Germany.

These sea lanes and their surrounding settlements
were rich with resources like, timber, wax,

wheat, resins and KhAnubis merch (which you
can now get by going to khanubis.tv and clicking

“store”, or clicking the link just below
NordVPN’s link), and also in merchants of
all different kinds of trades.

Basically, it was the perfect place to establish
a city in an online mobile game.

It was these such merchants which would eventually
give rise to the Hanseatic League.

Across the northern shores of modern-day Germany,
numerous guilds (known as “Hanse” in the

German of the time) were established for merchants
of the area to form and protect business partnerships
and trading relations.

In 1241, the cities of Lübeck and Hamburg
formed an alliance which was essentially the
precursor to the Hanseatic League.

Lübeck had access to the fishing grounds
(err… waters?) of the North and Baltic Seas,

while Hamburg controlled access to the salt
trade routes of Lüneburg.

Cologne joined this alliance in 1260, and
the Hansas continued to grow over the next

100 years, until the Hanseatic League was
truly formally established with the first
general diet of the Hansa in 1356 in Lübeck.

As the Hansas continued to expand, they came
into fierce competition with the trading powers

of Scandinavia, who had previously controlled
trade in these waters, at least until they

signed a treaty with Visby, which would become
part of the League.

The Hanseatic League wasn’t necessarily
an empire as we would know it in the traditional

sense, but was more of an economic and defensive
alliance between the merchant powers of the
region.

You see, this region didn’t have a strong
central power to govern it, and so… you
know, they kind of needed something.

Outside of their not-an-empire, the Hansas
established various foreign trading posts,
each known as a “kontor”, meaning office.

These kontore were established in many different
cities outside the League, including London,

Bergen, and Novgorod, with ports and warehouses
owned by the League.

The traders of the League would also often
establish trading settlements just outside--or

often in-- the walls of a new city they found
would be good for trading.

As the Hanseatic League was not a single kingdom
or empire, it had quite a unique political

structure for the time, with many experts
liking it to a kind of medieval European Union

in some ways (notably Britain’s reluctance
to get fully involved with them).

The League was essentially a conglomeration
of different merchant towns and city-states,

although it kind of fell somewhere slightly
in between a united state and a confederation
of independent city-states.

Perhaps the best way to describe it would
be as a highly structured defensive and trade
alliance.

The Hanseatic League did have an army, as
well as a legal system, taxes, and the member

cities would send envoys to the occasional
diet meeting in the capital of Lübeck.

Hanseatic traders were often even exempt from
local taxes and laws while trading abroad
in England, Scandinavia, or Russia.

The League thrived in this manner for a couple
hundred years, until it eventually met its

downfall, starting in the 16th century, as
they started getting territorially bullied

by the Swedish Empire and Denmark, and economically
bullied by the suddenly vastly prosperous
British and especially Dutch East India Companies.

As the foreign kontore also started to close
once their hosts started to stop liking them

as much due to often monopolistic actions
and not following local laws, the remaining

cities of the Hanseatic League also started
to look towards local interests, especially

as, you know, Germany was looking like it
was about to approach starting to be a thing.

Of course, putting together foreign traders
that want to trade in a city with low taxes

and a kingdom that wants to extract as much
in taxes as it can from said traders goes

about as well as spaghetti and chocolate,
or KhAnubis and not stealing joke prompts
from Half as Interesting.

In the last formal meeting of the Hanseatic
League in 1669, only 9 member cities remained,

and by the time of its disillusion in 1862
with the rise of Prussia, only 3 cities remained:
Hamburg, Lübeck, and Bremen.

Honestly though, respect to Hamburg and Lübeck
for playing it out until the very end, that’s
dedication!

Of course, nowadays the Hanseatic League is
basically just the geopolitical equivalent

of a pile of dust and barely anything remains
of it today, right?
Well, not really.

While the Hanseatic League might not really
be relevant today, their legacy is still very

visible across the areas they once traded
across.

Of course, the most visible source of this
is all the references that are made to it
in modern day Northern Europe.

For example, the German cities of Bremen,
Demmin, Greifswald, Hamburg, Lübeck, Lüneburg,

Rostock, Stade, Stralsund and Wismar, as well
as the Dutch cities of Groningen, Deventer,

Kampen, Zutphen and Zwolle, all call themselves
Hanseatic cities.

It’s not just the “Hanse Cities” though,
but also several organizations in the region,

from F.C. Hansa Rostock to the Hanze University
of Applied Sciences, Groningen to biggest

airline in Europe (if including its subsidiaries),
the Cologne-based Lufthansa (Luft [Air] Hansa).

Many experts even draw plenty of parallels
between the freely trading Hanseatic League
and the European Union of the current day.

Now, speaking of online security (somehow),
this video was sponsored by NordVPN.

When you think about it, NordVPN and the Hanseatic
League weren’t all too different, since

they were both focused on keeping their customers
safe from piracy.

Cringe-inducingly forced jokes aside, NordVPN
is a highly rated VPN service that allows

you to keep your data safe and sound from
malware and spyware by encrypting your data
into something called a VPN tunnel.

Of course, they also have over 5,000 servers
around the world that you can log onto in

more than 60 different countries (of course
I counted).
